This looks like a tipping point. In much larger West African #ebola outbreak in 2014, once the rate of new cases jumped solidly above 10 to 20 per day, the outbreak exploded.  Remember, that outbreak led to 28, 616 cases and some 11,300 deaths.  
 /5 >>> https://t.co/Wd6VcHWuHI

6. Last thing: A big part of transmission in this outbreak has been nosocomial spread ‚Äî people contracting #Ebola in clinics, hospitals, at traditional healers. A survey of health facilities in Katwa found very poor infection control (IPC) practices. Ebola spreads this way. https://t.co/zcScphJX7a

5. Here's how this happens: A woman in Kalunguta, south of Beni (near the x on the map) catches #Ebola. Her family tries to take her to a hospital a significant distance away. (red arrow) They were stopped at Beni (blue arrow). Other patient moves have been successful. https://t.co/KIIKRfV1HL

4. So often in this #Ebola outbreak transmission is halted in a location, only to be reignited because someone sick flees from point A to point Q. The fact that Beni is listed among the current transmission hotspots is evidence of this. Transmission there was stopped.
